Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Just like ZEC can't tell, HUSH can't tell

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> the video above explains it better than me, i think

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> regardless, if we don't migrate to Sapling, we are open to this bug, which basically means somebody can print a bunch of HUSH in zaddrs (currently there is 71000 HUSH in zaddrs, so if i want to stay under the radar, i print less than that) and then push it to a taddr and sell on an exchange. That is what an attack would look like

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> TLDR: Unfortunately, you gotta move everything to taddrs in prep to migrate to Sapling. Allowing Sprout zaddrs to go directly into Sapling zaddrs allows bad/toxic/counterfeit funds (if they exist) to go into the new system, which is why that is disallowed. The coin supply can be audited when funds pass thru taddrs during the transition

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> This is the latest paper explaining the Zcash sprout inflation bug. Warning, it gets into crazy math pretty fast: https://eprint.iacr.org/2019/119.pdf

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> not only does all that math need to be understood, the code that implements it needs to be understood and then the exploit coded to take advantage of it. With the deep math peoples usually not blockchain coders, the intersection of the two skillsets combined with actually looking at this in detail was like one, the zcash dev that found it

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> that being said, now the cat is out of the bag, any decent zero knowledge cryptographer could probably work with any decent blockchain coder and make an exploit, but isnt exactly inexpensive. about a million times easier to do a 51% attack, literally

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> yes, i agree and have thought about that as well. 51% attacks would be much easier than exploiting this bug, to put it into perspective for people. if James says 1 million times easier, I believe him

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> i guess not a million times easier than a dPoW protected chain... but there are plenty of non-dPoW zcash forks, so that is much easier target than this. of course, the sooner it is updated the better

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrd-hush] <Nixxen> I'm out of the loop. Just saw the Reddit post and thought it was some odd scam attempt but seems like you're talking about it here too.
In short, what's happening?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <paia> And the reason for not having both enabled is the sprout bug? Or is there another reason?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <heguli97> @Nixxen In short, Hush has to upgrade to Sapling in response to the Zcash Sprout inflation (CVE-2019-7167) bug. When the upgrade to Sapling happens, funds in transparent addresses (starting with t1) will be airdropped to the new version. Unfortunately, funds in shielded addresses (starting with zc) cannot be airdropped.  https://myhush.org/sapling/

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <paia> Why not komodo‚Äôs way of upgrade? Upgrade to sapling and give time to move coins from sprout to sapling?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <heguli97> Isn't it done in komodo's way? "Currently no cut-over time is set, but it will be decided soon. Shielded funds left in Sprout pool after a certain yet-undecided date WILL BE LOST."

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @paia "upgrade to sapling" is a a large complex process which prolongs the support of sprout. it's viable for KMD with their resources, not HUSH

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> KMD knew about this bug. ZEN+KMD were told, nobody else. KMD has been preparing for this for months. And has a lot more dev resources than HUSH. I am merely 0.01*(jl777) on a good day

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> KMD added sapling on Dec 15th and the activation date is today, in a few hours. they have been prepping for over 60 days and that code took a long time for jl777 before that

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <Matthias> Do you know if Tradesatoshi is going to keep HUSH under maintenance until this is fixed?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @Matthias we have no control over their behavior

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> they are dealing with the risk of somebody printing fake sprout funds and selling them on their exchange, and them possibly bearing the risk of that.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it's inconvenient, but also, it makes Hush not a good target for the attacker while we transition. Because the attacker would have very low liquidity to try to sell "fake" funds

[dscrd-hush] <heguli97> This message is from Berg on the 29th of October last year: 
"We just had email correspondence yesterday with positive news.
Hush markets will resume, per Cryptopia's email. We want to have a new Hush release ready so they don't have to double update since they tend to take their time with that kind of stuff....
We cannot have a timeline for how long it'll take for Cryptopia to resume, just know that we do have their intentions to do so in writing, and we are working diligently to get them to do so as soon as possible."
